title: November 26 - December 14, 2025
summary: Suno partners with Warner Music Group, Kling O1 model launches with production-ready quality, Disney invests $1 billion in OpenAI partnership bringing 200+ characters to Sora, Topaz Labs announces Starlight Precise 2 for Astra, comprehensive Veo 3 voice dubbing workflows revealed, McDonald's pulls AI Christmas commercial amid controversy, and Jon Erwin (House of David director) joins RealDreams HQ.
keyHighlights: Suno partners with Warner Music Group with new download restrictions
Kling O1 video model launches with production-ready quality
Disney invests $1 billion in OpenAI, brings 200+ characters to Sora
Topaz Labs announces Starlight Precise 2 for removing plastic look in AI videos
Comprehensive Veo 3 voice dubbing and accent consistency techniques shared
Jon Erwin (House of David director) joins RealDreams community

highlightTopic.title: üé¨ Disney & OpenAI Partnership
highlightTopic.description: Disney announced a groundbreaking partnership with OpenAI, investing $1 billion and bringing over 200 Disney, Marvel, and Star Wars characters to the Sora platform. This marks a dramatic shift from Disney's previous stance of suing Midjourney, representing a major validation of AI video generation technology by one of the world's largest entertainment companies. The deal signals Disney's commitment to AI-powered content creation and positions Sora as a key platform for character-driven storytelling.

items.title: üéµ Suno Partners with Warner Music Group
items.overview: ChristianF. announces groundbreaking partnership with Warner Music Group, reshaping AI music generation landscape.
items.description: ChristianF. announced that Suno has partnered with Warner Music Group in a major industry development. The partnership will allow downloads but with new restrictions - downloads will be limited to paid tiers with monthly caps on the number of downloads allowed. ChristianF. noted that Suno remains the best AI music generation tool and expressed hope that this partnership will level up the platform even further. Rory Flynn commented that Suno has gotten significantly better over the last year, with the community expressing optimism about the partnership's potential to enhance the platform while maintaining ethical music licensing practices.

items.title: üé¨ Disney Invests $1 Billion in OpenAI Partnership
items.overview: Edmond Yang and Chad Nelson share news of Disney partnering with OpenAI, bringing over 200 Disney, Marvel, and Star Wars characters to Sora with major investment.
items.description: Edmond Yang and Chad Nelson shared the groundbreaking news that Disney has signed a deal with OpenAI to bring more than 200 Disney, Marvel, and Star Wars characters to the Sora video generation platform, accompanied by a $1 billion investment. David Clark joked "Critterz on Disney Plus confirmed," while Rory Flynn noted the irony of this "big heel turn from suing Midjourney." Edmond Yang observed Disney is "joining the darkside instead of fighting it," and David Clark commented that wellness checks should be put out on anti-AI spokespersons. The partnership represents a dramatic shift in Disney's approach to AI, moving from legal opposition to major investment and collaboration.

items.title: üé• Kling O1 Model Launch
items.overview: Martin LeBlanc announces Kling's O1 model release with production-ready quality and enhanced capabilities.
items.description: Martin LeBlanc announced the launch of Kling's O1 model, which promises improved video generation capabilities with options for 3-10 second clips. ChristianF. shared examples demonstrating the model's video editing capabilities, noting the quality is "extremely good, production ready for some cases." The community discussed whether Kling O1 could serve as a Sora 2 watermark remover, with Jordan Daniel Chesney speculating on this potential use case. ChristianF. provided LinkedIn examples showcasing realistic outputs, with Cristobal from Runway claiming to make content in 2 hours using the new model. The release generated significant excitement for its production-ready quality and versatility.

items.title: ‚ú® Topaz Labs Announces Starlight Precise 2
items.overview: Monji, Henry, and Issa Sissoko discuss Topaz Labs introducing Starlight Precise 2 for Astra, targeting the plastic look problem in AI videos.
items.description: Monji, Henry, and Issa Sissoko discussed the announcement of Starlight Precise 2 from Topaz Labs, designed specifically to tackle the persistent "plastic look" issue in AI-generated videos. The tool focuses on enhancing realism by improving face and skin textures, addressing one of the most common complaints about AI video generation. The release is set to be integrated into the Astra platform, with early beta access expected soon. The community expressed enthusiasm about finally having a dedicated solution for this widespread problem.

items.title: üìù Screenburn Launches for Story Development
items.overview: Charles Kriel announces Screenburn platform launch to help writers develop stories from ideas to completed screenplays.
items.description: Charles Kriel announced the launch of Screenburn, a new platform designed to guide writers through the entire story development process. Set to officially launch at Content London, Screenburn offers structured guidance from initial idea conception all the way through to completed screenplays or manuscripts. The tool aims to bridge the gap between creative inspiration and finished scripts, providing writers with systematic support throughout their development journey.

items.title: üñºÔ∏è Freepik Fixes Image Upload Size Limit
items.overview: Martin LeBlanc reports Freepik resolving community-reported issues with reference image upload size limits.
items.description: After community feedback from Luka T, Jordan Daniel Chesney, and Rory Flynn about issues uploading reference images to Freepik, Martin LeBlanc reported the problem to the team and announced the fix. The image upload size limit was increased from a restrictive 10MB (which was too low even for iPhone photos) to a more appropriate size, resolving daily 4K image importing issues. Rory Flynn confirmed he was having 4K importing issues "basically all-day everyday" and expressed appreciation for the quick fix. The rapid response demonstrated Freepik's commitment to addressing user feedback.

items.title: üîó ChatGPT Adobe Integration Announced
items.overview: Justin Hackney and Ramon Guthrie share announcement of ChatGPT integrating with Adobe apps, enabling free photo and PDF editing capabilities.
items.description: Justin Hackney and Ramon Guthrie shared the announcement that ChatGPT now offers integration with Adobe applications, allowing users to edit photos and PDFs directly through Adobe apps without additional costs. This integration significantly expands ChatGPT's utility for creative professionals, providing seamless access to professional-grade editing tools within the ChatGPT interface. The feature represents a major step in AI-powered creative workflows.

items.title: üé≠ Jon Erwin Joins RealDreams Community
items.overview: House of David director Jon Erwin joins the RealDreams HQ community.
items.description: The community warmly welcomed Jon Erwin, director of "House of David," to RealDreams HQ. Ryan Phillips (Uncanny Harry), Ludovic (who worked with Jon in Greece for Season 2), Dale (who nearly worked on House of David), Ozan Sihay, Justin Hackney, BasvdE, Billy Boman, Jim Phillips, Edmond Yang, Henry, and Jordan Daniel Chesney all expressed excitement and admiration for Jon's work. Jon's presence in the community represents a significant bridge between traditional filmmaking and AI-powered content creation, bringing high-level production expertise to the group.

items.title: üçî McDonald's Pulls AI Christmas Commercial
items.overview: Winston Mayo, Billy Boman, and ChristianF. discuss McDonald's Netherlands withdrawing AI-generated Christmas commercial, sparking industry discussion.
items.description: Winston Mayo, Billy Boman, and ChristianF. discussed McDonald's Netherlands pulling their AI-generated Christmas commercial created in collaboration with The Sweetshop. The withdrawal sparked debate about whether it was due to backlash (though Billy Boman noted he didn't see Coke-level antagonism in comments), corporate intervention, or the quality of execution. ChristianF. shared a German article discussing the controversy, noting "lots of stupidity projected on AI" but suggesting the concept itself may have been too bold and satirical for a Christmas message. Billy Boman humorously noted that "a majority of people also willingly poison themselves with McDonalds," questioning the validity of public opinion. The incident raised questions about agencies doing AI commercials in-house and the different reception of AI content in Europe versus the US.

items.title: üé® Nano Banana Pro LoRA Dataset Generator
items.overview: Lovis Odin releases open-source tool for creating Nano Banana Pro training datasets.
items.description: Lovis Odin announced an open-source multi-angle training tool on Gaussian Splatting for Flux 2, with plans for Z-Image integration. The tool facilitates browser-based dataset generation for Nano Banana Pro without requiring server infrastructure. The release enables creators to more easily train custom LoRAs for consistent character and style generation across their projects.

items.title: üöÄ Z-Image Model Release
items.overview: PJ Accetturo and Zack Abrams discuss Z-Image launching as lightweight, high-quality image generation model.
items.description: PJ Accetturo and Zack Abrams discussed the release of Z-Image, with plans for base, reasoning, and edit models coming soon, hopefully within the month. Ramon Guthrie praised Z-Image-Turbo as "hands down the best most accessible and runnable, lightweight image generation model," running at only 6B parameters (half the size of Flux.1 Dev's 12 parameters) with superior quality and prompt understanding. The model is super easy to train LoRAs for, runs easily on Mac, and now has Controlnet support. Zack Abrams suggested Z-Image could rival Nano Banana Pro in their next release since both models are autoregressive rather than DiT-based.

items.title: üé¨ Runway Gen 4.5 Preview
items.overview: Billy Boman shares Runway showcasing Gen 4.5 capabilities in sizzle reel, though not yet publicly available.
items.description: Billy Boman shared a sizzle reel featuring Runway Gen 4.5 shots that looked "pretty spectacular," though he noted some Gen 4 content also looked impressive but was difficult to replicate. Rourke questioned if it was officially public, noting some shots were "mental." Winston Mayo cautioned that "sizzle reels in tech do that a lot," especially when creators have VFX or advertising backgrounds. ChristianF. confirmed it's not accessible yet, not even for CPP (Creator Partner Program) members, though it shows up in the Runway interface. Cristobal from Runway claimed to make realistic content in 2 hours with the new model.

items.title: üçé Apple StarFlow Release
items.overview: Luka T shares Apple releasing StarFlow model on Hugging Face.
items.description: Luka T shared the release of Apple's StarFlow model on Hugging Face, adding to the growing ecosystem of open-source AI tools available to creators.

items.title: üé§ Veo 3: Accent Consistency and Voice Dubbing Workflow
items.overview: Jordan Daniel Chesney shares comprehensive workflow for achieving consistent accents and realistic voice dubbing in Veo 3.

tutorial.technique: *Use heavy-handed and redundant accent prompting to achieve about 90% success at accent consistency, which is far more important for dubbing than other factors.*
tutorial.workflow: *Jordan Daniel Chesney's complete process: 1) Dial in the accent in Veo with redundant prompting, 2) Cut a dozen or so takes together as one MP3, 3) Toss that into ElevenLabs to create the voice, 4) When Voice Changing with the new voice, leave "Remove background noise" OFF.*
tutorial.key_insight: *It's essential to retain Veo's generated room tone and reverb for realism, rather than adding ambient SFX back in post. There's a "big increase in realism when you can retain some of Veo's generated room tone and reverb."*
tutorial.alternative_approaches: *Martin LeBlanc suggested adding back ambient SFX in the video editor, but Jordan Daniel Chesney explained the realism benefit of retaining Veo's audio. Edmond Yang noted he handles reverbs and room tone separately with his sound engineer, while Blvckl!ght suggested duplicating the audio track and processing voice and background separately for more control.*

items.title: üéôÔ∏è ADR Technique for Veo 3 Voice Matching
items.overview: Gabe Michael shares ADR workflow for precise voice pacing in Veo 3 productions.

tutorial.technique: *Record your own voice to match the pacing of Veo 3 generations, then use speech-to-speech to convert it to the target voice. This ensures the input is consistent with the visual pacing.*
tutorial.results: *Jim Phillips confirmed ADR worked well for him too, noting "a lot of work but it really makes a difference."*
tutorial.application: *This technique provides more precise control over timing and delivery compared to generating voice separately and trying to match it in post.*

items.title: üé¨ Veo 3: First-Person POV Technique
items.overview: Jordan Daniel Chesney explains how to maintain consistent first-person perspective in Veo 3.

tutorial.technique: *To maintain a handheld first-person POV in Veo 3, you must ensure the camera direction is consistently set throughout the scene.*
tutorial.key_principle: *Consistency in camera direction prompting is essential for achieving a stable first-person experience that doesn't break immersion.*

items.title: üéµ ElevenLabs SFX Tool for Ambient Sounds
items.overview: Martin LeBlanc and Edmond Yang discuss using ElevenLabs SFX tool for creating ambient audio.

tutorial.tool: *ElevenLabs' SFX tool is effective for creating ambient sounds to enhance video productions.*
tutorial.key_feature: *Edmond Yang enthusiastically noted it's "really good, especially when you can change the duration," providing flexible control over sound design elements.*

items.title: üéµ Suno: Controlling Male/Female Duets
items.overview: Matt and Winston Mayo explain how to control vocal duets in Suno.

tutorial.technique: *To orchestrate duets with Suno, specify singer roles in the lyrics using tags like [male] and [female].*
tutorial.application: *This enables distinct control over each singer's parts in a recording session, allowing for precise arrangement of vocal harmonies and call-and-response patterns.*

items.title: üé® Nano Banana Pro: Score_ Tags for Quality Control
items.overview: BasvdE and Henry explain the critical score_ tag system for optimizing Nano Banana Pro outputs.

tutorial.background: *Score_ tags are quality control triggers specific to the Pony Diffusion XL family (including Nano Banana Pro, Pony Realism, and AutismMix). These tags don't work on standard SD models - they're unique to how Pony models were trained on millions of rated images from Danbooru.*
tutorial.hierarchy: *score_9 (absolute best, masterpieces), score_8_up (high quality professional art), score_7_up (good quality), score_6_up (average), score_5_up (low quality), score_4 (bad quality, sketches).*
tutorial.best_practice: *In positive prompts, stack "score_9, score_8_up, score_7_up" to give the AI a large pool of high-quality training data. In negative prompts, use "score_4, score_5, score_6" to avoid low-quality outputs.*
tutorial.critical_warning: *BasvdE emphasized: "If you remove these tags from a Nano Banana Pro prompt, the model gets confused and will likely generate an image that looks 'fried,' blurry, or like a child's drawing."*

items.title: üé® Nano Banana Pro: Storyboard Grid Generation
items.overview: Winston Mayo and Martin LeBlanc share prompts for generating storyboard grids.

tutorial.prompt: *Winston Mayo's go-to prompt: "show me the scene sequence in a 9 panel storyboard in the same style of image 1 in 16:9 aspect ratio, no words."*
tutorial.effectiveness: *Martin LeBlanc and Linus Ekenstam confirmed they use similar approaches, describing it as "very powerful" for quickly visualizing scene sequences and shot progression.*

items.title: üé® Nano Banana Pro: Extracting Images from Grids
items.overview: Community shares techniques for extracting and enhancing individual images from grid generations.

tutorial.problem: *ChristianF. asked about the best method for extracting single images from 3x3 grids without losing detail.*
tutorial.solution_1: *Edmond Yang's approach: crop the image then feed it back to Nano Banana Pro.*
tutorial.solution_2: *Billy Boman explained that Nano Banana Pro can "in some circumstances, sharpen and add textures back," but results depend on content - faces might lose likeness, complex logos or small text might not work. He suggested either zoom-cropping the needed image or asking Nano Banana Pro to isolate it through prompting and/or marking the desired section with a red outline.*
tutorial.solution_3: *Winston Mayo added you can prompt "extra photo number 1 on the top right as a single stand alone frame" or use the Dor Brothers tool, though it sometimes adds unwanted text.*

items.title: üé• Kling O1: Lipsync and Body Language Control
items.overview: Edmond Yang and Martin LeBlanc discuss character motion control with Kling O1 and Omni Human.

tutorial.technique: *Use Kling O1 with the Omni Human model for character animation. While Kling O1's lipsync may not match professional standards, it provides decent results when combined with Omni Human for full upper body tracking.*
tutorial.control_level: *Martin LeBlanc noted that adding to the prompt "feels like prompting the video model," giving substantial control over gestures and body language.*

items.title: ‚¨ÜÔ∏è SeedVR2: Best General Video Upscaler
items.overview: Luka T, Jordan Daniel Chesney, and Martin LeBlanc discuss SeedVR2 as the top upscaling solution.

tutorial.recommendation: *Luka T declared SeedVR2 "THE best general upscaler right now" after extensive testing. Jordan Daniel Chesney strongly agreed, stating he uses it exclusively for video upscaling (while preferring Magnific for images).*
tutorial.technical_settings: *Martin LeBlanc provided guidance from internal testing: use the 7B model (not 3B) with batch size 33 and temporal overlap of 4 frames to avoid flickering. Without proper temporal overlap settings, you get significant flickering.*
tutorial.comparison: *Martin LeBlanc noted that with the right settings it's good, but questioned if it's better than Topaz, requesting comparison examples.*

items.title: üé¨ Veo 3: Specific Lift Mechanics Prompting
items.overview: Gabe Michael shares technique for generating clean weightlifting movements in Veo 3.

tutorial.achievement: *Gabe Michael achieved impressive weightlifting animations in his "Cheddar Joe" submission entirely with Veo 3.1, without using video-to-video.*
tutorial.technique: *Prompt "very specific lift mechanics" in detail, which Veo sometimes follows successfully.*
tutorial.context: *Rory Flynn was amazed by how clean the lift motions were, noting he's had issues with those in the past and that "AI also hates bicep curls for some reason."*
tutorial.principle: *This demonstrates the importance of technical specificity when prompting complex physical movements.*

items.title: üé® Magnific Skin Enhancer: Makeup Removal Feature
items.overview: Linus Ekenstam shares Magnific's new makeup removal capability.

tutorial.feature: *Magnific Skin Enhancer now includes a feature to remove makeup from images, expanding the tool's capabilities for realistic skin rendering and character consistency work.*

items.title: üñºÔ∏è Freepik: Parallel Generation Strategy
items.overview: Martin LeBlanc and Max explain how to run multiple Nano Banana Pro generations simultaneously.

tutorial.question: *Edmond Yang asked about running more than one generation at a time on Freepik.*
tutorial.solution: *Max explained: "Use spaces and batch. That makes more gen parallel possible." Martin LeBlanc confirmed you can make 4 generations in parallel, significantly speeding up workflow for projects requiring multiple iterations or variations.*

items.title: üé® Nano Banana Pro: Structured Style Descriptions
items.overview: Henry demonstrates using Gemini to create reusable style descriptions for Nano Banana Pro.

tutorial.technique: *Use Gemini to describe styles using structured language with weights, then copy-paste these descriptions across projects to retain consistent style and aesthetics.*
tutorial.assessment: *While Henry noted it's "not as good as SREF somehow," it's still very versatile for maintaining visual consistency across a body of work.*

items.title: üéÆ Edmond Yang: Granniest Grandma (Interactive Game + Film)
items.overview: Edmond Yang creates interactive browser game to accompany Wonder Film Festival submission.
items.description: Edmond Yang submitted an innovative project combining a 16-minute animated film with a fully playable browser game at granniestgrandma.com. Yonatan called the game "addicting," joking "I had stuff to do today." Justin Hackney praised the dual format: "Love the style bro. And mental you made a mini game as well." The project demonstrates the expanding possibilities of AI-generated content beyond traditional formats, blending interactive entertainment with narrative filmmaking.

items.title: üí™ Gabe Michael: Cheddar Joe (Weightlifting Comedy)
items.overview: Gabe Michael creates comedy short featuring detailed weightlifting animations entirely in Veo 3.1.
items.description: Gabe Michael's "Cheddar Joe" submission showcased remarkably clean weightlifting mechanics achieved entirely with Veo 3.1 (no video-to-video). Rory Flynn was impressed by the lift motions, and Jordan Daniel Chesney called it a "masterpiece," loving "every second." The project demonstrated Veo 3.1's capability for complex physical movements when prompted with specific mechanics.

items.title: üëª Ryan Phillips: Uncanny Harry (4K Horror Comedy)
items.overview: Ryan Phillips delivers polished horror comedy with unexpected narrative twist.
items.description: Ryan Phillips released "Uncanny Harry" in 4K, with Rory Flynn noting he "totally thought that was going in another direction after the first scene" but found it "really well done." The project showcased sophisticated narrative misdirection and polished production values.

items.title: üéì Billy Boman: Student Success Story
items.overview: Billy Boman's student creates impressive work after just 3 weeks of instruction.
items.description: Billy Boman proudly shared his student Amanda Sandorov's final project after only 3 weeks of training, calling it "honestly better than a majority of AI stuff I see on a regular basis." The student applied to the Wonder Film Festival with the work, with Billy Boman noting she's a "strong contender." The project demonstrates the rapid learning curve possible with proper instruction in AI filmmaking tools.

items.title: ü§ñ Martin LeBlanc: Robot Hand Detail Test
items.overview: Martin LeBlanc tests video generator's ability to handle complex transparent mechanical details.
items.description: Martin LeBlanc conducted an experiment testing whether video generators could accurately render a robot hand with gaps showing the background between mechanical parts - details not visible in the reference video. The test pushed the boundaries of what video models can infer and generate for complex mechanical structures.

items.title: üé¨ Alex: Animation Submission
items.overview: Alex creates and submits animated project to Wonder Studios.
items.description: Alex shared his animation submission to Wonder Studios, expressing pride in the work. Winston Mayo noted "everyone is doing animations," highlighting the trend toward animated content in the community's submissions.

items.title: üíº Wonder Studios: Part-Time Moderator Position
items.overview: Benny announces Wonder App seeking experienced community moderator with solid moderation background.
items.description: Benny announced that Wonder App is hiring a Part-Time Moderator. The position requires solid experience in moderating and growing online communities, with the ability to confidently manage and curate high-quality account spaces. Interested candidates can apply through the provided Greenhouse link.

items.title: üé≠ AI Acting Limitations and Future Potential
items.overview: Community debates current state of AI acting capabilities and need for specialized models.
items.description: Yonatan, Chad Nelson, and ChristianF. engaged in discussion about AI's current inability to replicate nuanced acting, despite examples of emotional output. The consensus was that acting-centric AI models are needed to close this gap, as current tools struggle with the subtlety and intentionality that defines compelling performances.

items.title: üé¨ Celebrity Culture vs. AI Innovation
items.overview: Jordan Daniel Chesney discusses industry resistance to AI stemming from nostalgia for traditional celebrity culture.
items.description: Jordan Daniel Chesney posited that resistance toward AI in the entertainment industry may stem from nostalgia for traditional celebrity culture. He contrasted this with a forward-looking approach that values potential and innovation over past conventions. Chad Nelson and Adrian Daniel Botnariu joined the discussion, exploring how this tension shapes industry adoption of AI tools.

items.title: üì∫ Netflix HBO Max Acquisition Impact
items.overview: Discussion of Netflix's potential $5 billion penalty and HBO Max acquisition implications.
items.description: Issa Sissoko shared analysis suggesting Netflix might pay a $5 billion penalty related to the HBO Max acquisition. Gary Palmer expressed doubt that HBO Max was ever the revenue driver desired, anticipating "pretty aggressive org restructuring on the HBO/WB side." He noted Netflix is "a very well oiled machine and the WB tree will be shaken to follow suit." Ramon Guthrie emphasized that HBO is known for quality and highest viewership programs, warning that if they "drop the ball and mess that up, then it is not HBO." The discussion highlighted concerns about maintaining quality standards during major corporate transitions.

items.title: üé¨ Production Team Size vs. Quality
items.overview: Debate on whether large production teams enhance or hinder AI animation quality.
items.description: Billy Boman questioned whether 30 artists are really needed for AI productions, sharing an Instagram reel. Jim Phillips noted that for 6 episodes it's "definitely a nice to have if the original vision is maintained," citing his experience on an anime feature with just two artists - "beautiful results, but a real slog when it came to shot creation relative to a production schedule." Billy Boman countered that "disjointed styles will be prominent," noting some shots in the trailer lacked texture and art direction, requiring "such a tight ship and really have a rigid workflow to keep consistency throughout." Jim Phillips agreed: "When a production has the time, fewer hands in the pot almost always leads to stronger work. It's often the difference between true artistry and assembly-line output."

items.title: üé® Weavy Node-Based Workflows Adoption
items.overview: Community discusses adoption of Weavy's node-based approach for AI image generation.
items.description: Blair asked how many in the community use Weavy as a baseline. Jim Phillips, just starting with an annual plan, expressed enthusiasm. Alex was getting up to speed. Billy Boman found nodes "kinda boring and overkill most of the time" but remained open to changing as the landscape evolves. Jim Phillips explained his use case: "I'm looking for repeatable results and am attempting to build systems based on one establishing shot - so it's an ideal workflow for me. A lot like building a custom GPT." The discussion highlighted different approaches to systematic versus intuitive creative workflows.

items.title: üé® Nano Banana Pro Celebrity Face Problem
items.overview: Blair raises concern about Nano Banana Pro's tendency to generate celebrity likenesses.
items.description: Blair asked if the group had discussed how "Nano pro tends to want to turn your characters into famous people." This highlighted an ongoing challenge with AI image generation models trained on large datasets containing celebrity images, raising questions about character consistency and unintended likeness generation.

items.title: üé® Grok 4.1 as Best Anime Model
items.overview: Alex declares Grok 4.1 the superior anime generation model despite resolution limitations.
items.description: Alex boldly stated "Grok 4.1 is the best anime model out there at the moment. Change my mind." Jim Phillips agreed enthusiastically. Henry noted the downside: "Too bad for the low resolution right now though. The upscale isn't doing much." Ryan Phillips concurred: "it animates 2D stuff really impressively, if the resolution was higher I'd use it but for now it's in the only for phone zone for me." The discussion highlighted the trade-off between quality and resolution in current anime-focused models.

items.title: üíº Public Founder Disputes on LinkedIn
items.overview: Community discusses founder airing grievances publicly about failed business relationships.
items.description: Billy Boman shared a LinkedIn post where a founder publicly aired grievances about being mistreated, questioning the "lets air our dirty laundry publicly" approach. Adrian Daniel Botnariu defended it as authentic artist behavior: "he's an impulsive dude... it puts him more into the artist category, over business. Voicing your opinions openly is part of the job. Shaping culture is part of the job." Billy Boman countered it felt "a little sanctimonious" with the "I'm doing this for everyone else" framing, suggesting it was really about throwing shade at people who wronged him. Henry added that he sees "regular humble bragging" from this person with claims of "signed my first feature" and "huge brand" but never seeing relevant work, noting "airing like this on X, LinkedIn, etc...makes you look like a difficult person, not like a champion."

items.title: üé¨ LED Wall Techniques for AI Video
items.overview: Winston Mayo and Ludovic discuss using AI-generated content on large LED displays.
items.description: Winston Mayo asked if anyone had experience with big interactives for LED displays like museums. Ludovic later shared his approach to utilizing AI-generated video on large LED walls, discussing challenges like upscaling limitations and creative solutions to fill expansive screens despite technical constraints. David Clark and PJ Accetturo contributed to the discussion about practical implementation strategies.

items.title: üé¨ Allianz: High-Quality AI Background Replacement
items.overview: Albert Bozesan highlights Allianz's impressive AI background replacement work.
items.description: Albert Bozesan shared what he called "the highest quality AI background replacement I've seen," noting that Allianz is letting their video head Robert "go nuts with all the tools." He expressed surprise but enthusiasm that a major insurance company is embracing AI video tools so openly and effectively.
